I suppose this feature still exists — on a static HTML site using straight HTML it’s possible to use “Server Side Includes”. However, nowadays there are several “Static Site Generator” systems. I know the one I created, AkashaCMS - the powerful static file CMS to build your dream website — In such a system you write content in, for example Markdown, then run some software to render the Markdown files into HTML for your website using layout templates. In AkashaCMS you have several capabilities to have reusable code snippets that are used across the site such as in the header and footer. First is a layout template — each file declares which template it is to be rendered with. The template contains the full HTML for that type of page, and of course the site designer sets up each page as they wish. Second is what’s called a “partial”. These are code snippets that can be used anywhere on a page. This is the most likely place to have a common header/footer for the entire site. You create one Partial for the header, another for the footer, then every page layout template uses the Partial’s for header and footer.
